response: narrative=Max Marshall was last seen leaving a study group held at Larkfield Road, Inverclyde. He failed to return to 1 Customhouse Way and was reported missing by his foster guardian. A colleague from the study group confirmed Max's departure but wasn't aware of any issues.

narrative=Max Marshall, a young boy living at 1 Customhouse Way, PA15 1EG, was reported missing after he failed to return home from a planned trip to a local shopping mall. It was uncovered that Max had been disowned by his biological family due to unexplained circumstances and was living with his foster mother. According to a colleague of the foster mother, Max was last seen at the train station while possibly trying to make sense of his life changes. Shaun Cook, who was assisting in the search effort, noted Max's fascination with trains, which might have led him to wander off. Police traced Max to Larkfield Road, Inverclyde, PA16 0XN, concluding the search successfully after just over two hours of intense searching.

narrative=Max Marshall was last seen at a study group at 1 Newark Street. He was supposed to meet Tracey Cooper at an airport nearby, but never arrived. Concern grew when Ruth Booth, his guardian, reported him missing. Max was later found safe on Larkfield Road. It seems he had visited a friend's house on his way home, delaying his return.

narrative=Max Marshall, 11, was reported missing after he was last seen at a train station. Before his disappearance, he had a disagreement with his foster father, Keith Brown, feeling disowned by his family. Max was a frequent visitor to Railway Pier, Oban, PA34 4LW, and had been observed spending time at a nearby rest area and alleyway. On the day of his disappearance, witnesses recall seeing him at the truck stop located on Glengallen Road, Oban, PA34 4HH, alone and seemingly distressed. Despite initial fears, Max was later found unharmed in a rest area by police after being discovered during a routine check. His brief time away highlighted challenges within his foster care situation.

narrative=Max Marshall, an 11-year-old boy in foster care, was last seen by a colleague of his family at a nearby train station. His disappearance sparked concerns when he failed to return to his residence at 1 Customhouse Way, PA15 1EG. The young boy was known to be fascinated with trucks, and there were indications he might have been drawn to the local truck stop around Larkfield Road, Inverclyde, PA16 0XN. Max, eventually traced by staff, was found safe several hours later on Glengallen Road, Oban, PA34 4HH. There, he explained his curiosity drove him to explore areas beyond his usual environment, providing relief to those worried about his well-being.

narrative=Max Marshall was last seen at a train station in Oban, heading towards music lessons. Despite his young age, his high initial risk level was noted due to challenging circumstances, including being disowned by his birth family and placed in foster care. His foster mother, who usually picked him up, contacted the police when he failed to return home. A thorough search ensued, focusing on common locations a child might frequent. His colleague from school mentioned a fascination with vehicles, leading responders to canvass the nearby rest area and a bustling truck stop. Ultimately, police successfully located him near the airport, attempting to find his way back home. Max was returned safely, his risk level reassessed as low.

narrative=Max Marshall, a 12-year-old, was last seen at a train station after leaving from a friend's house located at 1 Customhouse Way, PA15 1EG. Having been disowned by his family, Max was living in foster care at the time of his disappearance. It was suspected that his emotional turmoil may have driven him to seek solitude, as he was known to wander into wilderness areas. One of his colleagues, June Parkinson, mentioned seeing him at a nearby truck stop, speaking to long-haul drivers about places far away. Another witness spotted Max near an alleyway close to the train station, seemingly hesitant and uncertain about where he intended to go next. Intensive searches were conducted after his absence was reported, ultimately leading to his safe tracing at Railway Pier, Oban, PA34 4LW where he was found by the police.

narrative=Max Marshall, a 12-year-old boy from Winchester, was last seen at a truck stop near 1 Newark Street, PA14 5PE. Max, who had been disowned by his birth family and was staying with his foster mother, was reported missing after failing to return home. Max was later found safe near North Pier, Oban, PA34 5QD, by his foster family's collaborative efforts.

narrative=Max Marshall, a 12-year-old under foster care, was reported missing. Disowned by his biological family, Max had been in the care of his foster parents, Lucy Andrews and Keith Brown. Last seen at a local train station, Max was believed to be trying to reconnect with his past or find a new beginning. Although initially assessed as low risk, his young age prompted concern. The investigation led authorities to various locations, including an alleyway near Railway Pier, Oban, PA34 4LW, and eventually to Glengallen Road, Oban, PA34 4HH. Max was found at a nearby truck stop, unharmed, and brought back to safety by the police.
